ygData.subject: Cantera 1.5.5, new simplified Windows build procedure
ygData.msgSnippet: I have just changed the Cantera version number to 1.5.5, and posted a Windows source distribution at the sourceforge site (cantera-1.5.5-src.zip). The big

From: David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...>
Subject: Cantera 1.5.5, new simplified Windows build procedure
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

I have just changed the Cantera version number to 1.5.5, and posted a 
Windows source distribution at the sourceforge site 
(cantera-1.5.5-src.zip).

The big news: Cantera can now be completely built  from within Visual 
Studio .NET, including the Python and MATLAB interfaces.  You can also 
create your own binary installer programs (.msi files) and distribute 
them to install Cantera (+ your own application code) on machines that 
do not have Visual Studio.

Now there is no need to have cygwin (but personally I would install it 
anyway), or to do anything from a command line, or to have Fortran.  I 
think virtually all Windows installation problems should be gone now.  
(Also, the Python location is no longer hard-wired to C:\PYTHON23.)

The procedure is described step-by-step in a Powerpoint presentation I 
have also posted at the Sourceforge site under "Cantera Documentation" 
- see file cantera-vc7.ppt.

Other than that, you may notice a new class "Mixture" in Python, and a 
couple of new classes (MultiPhase and MultiPhaseEquil) in C++. These 
implement multi-phase mixtures and a new multi-phase equilibrium 
solver.  It is fully functional in Python and C++ now (MATLAB soon), 
but is not documented, so its official introduction will be in Cantera 
1.6 which will be out in January.  Cantera 1.6 will contain also some 
new phase models, and some improved support for non-ideal phases.

Windows people in particular - if you have Visual C++ .NET, please try 
out the new build procedure, and report any problems.
